metadata.title: Frictional performance evaluation of sliding surfaces lubricated by zinc-oxide nano-additives

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 2 January 2019 Revised 9 May 2019 Accepted 13 May 2019
KEYWORDS Sliding friction; piston ring/ cylinder liner contact; ZnO nano-additives; anti-wear/ friction

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Lubricant enhancers were first used at the beginning of the nineteenth century, starting with organic friction modifiers as anti-wear and friction modifier additives, continuing to the use of nanoparticles (NPs) after 2010 [1]. Engine oils are formulated from base oils composed of petroleum-based hydrocarbons that involve organic compounds (carbon and hydrogen or polyalphaolefins (PAO)). Engine oils also contain 10–30 wt% of modifiers/additives [2]. Oil lubrication is very important for automobiles and equipment to maintain durability, cleanliness and cooling for the rubbing moving parts and lower the friction and wear rates of the rubbing surfaces to save fuel energy [3,4]. Researchers have been interested in improving the characteristics of lubricants using nanoscale-based materials as nanoadditives that could be added to both liquid and solid lubricants, such as ZnO [5], WS2 [6], CuO [7], diamond, graphene oxide, TiO2 and Al2O3. [8,9]. Nanomaterial lubrication additives have an essential role in improving the tribological behaviour of engines, fuel economy and lubricant lifecycles [1,10].
In the literature, on lubrication with nanomaterials, scholars have investigated and characterised several nanomaterials as nano-lubricant additives. Nanomaterial enhancers in commercialised lube oil improve the
tribological behaviour of automotive engines. For instance, in petrol engines, Ali et al. [11] revealed that the dissipated power in friction and wear of the piston assembly ranges from 40% to 50% of the overall power losses. The authors added Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid NPs with an 8–12 nm average particle size for Al2O3 and 10 nm for TiO2 in commercial engine oil (Castrol 5W-30) with a nanomaterial concentration of 0.25 wt%. The results of several tribotests at 0.5–5.7 MPa and 0.5–1.2 m s−1 at 100°C showed that the nanomaterial additive improved the friction by 40–50% and the wear rate by 20–30%. This occurred due to the formation of a protective film on worn surfaces called a nano-tribofilm. Aldana et al. [12] examined the effect of 1 wt-% WS2 and 1 wt-% anti-wear additive ZDDP in PAO base oil to evaluate the tribological behaviour of WS2 NPs; experiments were conducted on four samples: pure PAO, PAO+WS2, PAO + ZDDP and PAO+ WS2/ZDDP at boundary regime conditions of 100°C, 3 mm s−1 and 1.12 GPa. The results revealed that the tribological behaviour of the PAO+WS2 improved the wear rate by 50% and reduced friction by 30% compared with pure PAO. WS2 contributed the most to the formation of the tribofilm. However, the best tribological behaviour of WS2 was observed in the presence of ZDDP, which protects the WS2
© 2019 Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining Published by Taylor & Francis on behalf of the Institute
CONTACT Hou Xianjun houxj@whut.edu.cn Hubei Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Automotive Components, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, People’s Republic of China; Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Automotive Components Technology, Wuhan 430070, People’s Republic of China. *Ahmed Elagouz (ahmedelagouz@mu.edu.eg) and Mohamed Kamal Ahmed Ali (eng.m.kamal@mu.edu.eg) contributed equally to this work.
layers from oxidation and enhances the properties of the friction modifier.
Among various nano-lubricants, metallic oxides with a compact and stable structure and acceptable thermal stability are promising green lubricant additives. For instance, metallic oxide ZnO NPs offer potential advantages such as a large surface area, high surface energy, strong adsorption, high diffusion, easy sintering, good tribological characteristics and low melting point [13,14]. Additionally, the ZnO NPs are free of sulphur and phosphorus and are thus environment-friendly. The literature shows [15] that ZnO NPs have good anti-friction and anti-wear capabilities. Battez et al. [16] studied the tribological behaviour of ZnO NPs (20 nm) blended in PAO base lube oil and found the ZnO NPs can form effective tribofilms that show superior tribological properties. Jianhua et al. [13] reported that 125 nm of ZnO prepared by the homogeneous deposition method in the presence of sodium lauryl sulphate as the surfactant can reduce friction and wear by 10–30% and 20–40%, respectively, under 100–500 N normal loads at 1450 rev min−1, room temperature and a 30-min testing period on a four-ball machine.
In general, the boundary regime is an extremely dangerous event in lubrication systems that is worthy of being avoided if possible. The friction trend increases to a high level within the boundary lubrication region, as given in the Stribeck curve [11]. In the boundary lubrication event, the asperities of worn surfaces come into significant contact with each other, and this regime can occur due to the following conditions: startup and shutdown of equipment, low speed or under high load conditions. Figure 1 shows the boundary friction system in a piston ring/cylinder liner assembly camshaft and journal bearings. Within the boundary regime, if the oil film thickness is not enough to overcome the roughness of the sliding surfaces or if
the oil viscosity is low, valleys, grooves and microcracks will form on the worn surfaces because of abrasive and adhesive wear [17,18]. Aldana et al. [12] reported a 70% friction reduction in the boundary lubrication system using nano-lubrication compared with the base lube oil.
The literature indicates that oxides have good resistance to wear and several metal oxides have been used as lubricant additives, including ZnO, TiO2, CuO, Fe3O4, Cr2O3 and Al2O3 [19–21]. The selection of nanomaterials is very important in improving the tribological performance and reinforcing the properties of engine oils [22]. At elevated temperatures, ZnO can function as a lubricant to diminish the friction and wear of rubbing surfaces in rolling and sliding contacts [23]. Owing to the characteristics of the ZnO NPs, nanostructured ZnO possesses unique physical, chemical and biological properties. Because of its non-toxic nature and ability to block UV radiation, ZnO is widely applicable in numerous applications such as cosmetics and coating systems. Additionally, ZnO has a wide bandgap (3.37 eV) and large exciton binding energy of 60 meV and thus is a good material for optical applications [24].
In recent decades, nanomaterials have been used in engine oils as nano-additives to form an indirect protective coating layer on the frictional surfaces that is deposited on the ring-liner surfaces through a tribological reaction. Generally, direct-coated surfaces lose thickness over time, and nano-additives provide a self-replenishing tribofilm layer on the sliding surfaces that acts as an indirect protective coating layer [8]. Thus, the main purpose of this study is to evaluate the lubricating performance of ZnO NPs as nano-additives in commercial lube oil, Shell Helix 10W-40, under various loads and speeds of 46-308 N and 0.138– 0.666 m s−1, respectively, at room temperature to achieve a boundary lubrication system. The tribological tests were carried out using a ring-on-liner test bench
to imitate the ring/liner sliding in vehicular engines. ZnO NP nano-additives were chosen to reinforce the tribological performance of the lube oil because of their aforementioned potential described in the literature. X-ray diffraction (XRD), FE-SEM, XPS, EDS and a 3D optical profiler (Bruker, Contour GT-I 3D) were used to analyse the worn surfaces to detect the friction and wear properties and the activation mechanisms of the nano-lubricant formulations.
The remainder of this paper is organised as follows. The first section explains the experimental set-up and sample preparations. The second section includes the results and discussion and describes the friction and wear behaviour for the ZnO and 10W-40 lubrication and the ring-liner surface morphologies. Finally, the conclusion and some future recommendations are reported in the third section.

sections.heading: Characterisation of the ZnO NPs
sections.text: The ZnO NPs were obtained from XFNANO Company, China. Figure 2(a) shows the morphology of the ZnO NPs. The morphology of the ZnO NPs was spherical, which offers a good rolling medium within the engine oil between the rubbing surfaces. The ZnO NPs have an average grain size of approximately 20 nm, purity of 99% and specific surface area of 21.5 m2 g−1 according to the information provided from the XFNANO company. The crystal nanostructure of the ZnO nano-additives was analysed by XRD analysis, as shown in Figure 2 (b). Three strong diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32°, 35° and 37° can be observed, which are attributed to (1 0 0), (0 0 2), (1 0 1) of the ZnO NPs. These are the typical peaks of pure ZnO NPs. Moreover, all the diffraction peaks were well-matched with those of the standard pattern of bulk ZnO NPs (JCPDS NO. 36-1451) [25].

sections.heading: Formulation of ZnO nano-lubricants
sections.text:
In this study, the fully formulated commercial engine oil (10W-40) was considered a reference oil to exhibit
the effects of ZnO NPs as friction/wear modifiers. The main engine oil specifications (10W-40) are presented in Table 1. The kinematic viscosity and viscosity index of the oil samples were measured according to the GB/T265-1988 and GB/T1995-1998 testing standards, respectively, at Wuhan Runjia Lubrication Products Testing Consulting Co., Ltd. The ZnO nanolubricant samples comprised 98% reference oil, 2 wt% oleic acid (OA) and different concentrations of ZnO NPs (0.1, 0.3, 0.6 and 0.8 wt-%). OA was used as a solvent to disperse the ZnO nano-additives in the reference oil. The 2 wt-% OA was selected because this concentration offers a very stable mixture without any separation problems. The presence of OA contributed more to the dispersibility of the ZnO NPs and stability of the nano-lubricant than to the anti-friction properties. Moreover, it is sufficiently low to not affect the viscosity of the reference oil. These results are in agreement with those obtained in the literature [13]. The blending of the ZnO nano-lubricant specimens was performed by a mechanical stirring device (85-2 type constant temperature magnetic stirrer) for 4 h to obtain a homogeneous stable suspension. Figure 3(a) displays the ZnO nano-lubricant samples with four concentrations after the preparation process at the room temperature. It was apparent that the reference oil containing oleic acid was brighter and had a clear light brown colour.
To check the stability of the ZnO nano-lubricants, the UV−Visible spectroscopy was used to elucidate the stability of the ZnO NPs in the reference oil. The stability of the formulated ZnO nano-lubricants was monitored at a 489 nm (λmax) wavelength for 8 days, as shown in Figure 3(b). The UV results show that the dispersibility of the ZnO NPs showed good stability for 336 h after the nano-lubricant preparation.
Notably, the stability of the ZnO NPs depends on time; the ZnO nano-lubricant stability decreased with increasing storage time due to sedimentation of the ZnO NPs in the reference oil. Aggregation of the ZnO NPs occurs whenever the Brownian motion and Van der Waals attractive forces of the NPs are greater than the repulsive forces based on the theory developed by Derjaguin, Landau, Verwey and Overbeek (DLVO theory) [26]. Further investigation is needed to measure the stability of the ZnO nano-lubricants for longer periods and study the factors affecting the dispersion stability.
Description of the tribometer and frictional samples
The sliding-based-tribotest bench of a piston ring/ cylinder liner assembly was used to mimic the reciprocating action of the internal combustion engines in accordance with ASTM G181-11 [27]. A detailed full structural diagram of the sliding-based-tribometer is shown in Figure 4, and was used to study the
friction/wear behaviour with ZnO nano-additives. In the tribometer, the friction force was measured during the testing time using a piezoelectric force sensor (Type: LDCZL-ZY, Serial No: LD146040834, Sensitivity of 1.8 mV/V/N). The frictional force signal was amplified by the AMP03 amplifier and the signal was received and processed by a data acquisition interface using the DEWE Soft 6.6.7 platform. The sliding speed was controlled by a 1.5 kW AC motor integrated with a rotational speed controller. The rotational speed was measured by a digital tachometer (HT-4200). The normal force was applied vertically (Z-axis) on the piston ring specimen.
In this set-up, the test specimens are pieces from unworn ring and liner to ensure that the sample surfaces used in the tests have the same surface roughness. The dimensions of the running face for the piston ring sample were 10.3 mm × 1.2 mm. The ring and liner samples were cut from petrol engine components. The technical specifications of the engine were model HXDG16-BD-TJ, 4 cylinders in line, 4-stroke watercooled, 75 mm cylinder bore and 1600 cm3 swept volume. The primary mean surface roughness (Ra) of the ring and liner were 0.58 and 0.67 μm, respectively. The surface roughness was measured using a Nanovea ST400 3D Profilometer in accordance with ISO 25178. The ring and liner hardness were 320 and 413 Vickers hardness, respectively. The Vickers hardness was measured using an HVS-1000 Vickers hardness instrument (Beijing Times Peak Technology Co. Ltd., Beijing, China). The crystalline structures and phases of the frictional samples (ring and liner) were determined by XRD using CuKα radiation at 30 kV and 40 mA at a scanning speed of 0.01° s−1. The XRD data were analysed with MDI Jade 6. As shown in Figure 5, the main phase was Fe–Cr (ferrite), the key element of the frictional samples. For the ring and liner samples, the typical diffraction peaks of chromium–iron (Fe– Cr) are located at 2θ = 44.82°, 65.18° and 82.60° indexed to the (1 1 0), (2 0 0) and (2 1 1) planes, respectively. The most obvious diffraction peaks of
Figure 3. (a) Photograph of the lube oil samples after preparation. (b) UV time history of the ZnO nano-lubricants (0.6 wt-% NPs) for 8 days at λmax = 489 nm.
the Fe–Cr were strongly indexed according to the JCPDS card 41-1466. The iron–silicon (Fe3Si) peaks appeared in the XRD pattern of the liner at 2θ = 45.33°, 66.05° and 83.74° indexed to the (2 2 0), (4 0 0) and (4 2 2) planes, respectively, which are indexed according to the JCPDS card 45-1207.

sections.heading: Tribological testing
sections.text:
In this research, the effects of the normal force and sliding speed on the tribological behaviour of the ring-on-liner interface were investigated using ZnO nano-lubricant additives. The compression ring was used for the frictional experiments. The compression ring works under oil starvation during most of the strokes due to the action of the oil scraper ring. Hence, to mimic the properties of the compression ring lubrication under oil starvation, the lube oil added between the rubbing interfaces should be limited to a small quantity (4.5 mL), as previously reported [11,28]. The influence of lube oil starvation considerably reduces the lube oil thickness and thus it is appropriate that this starvation case provides support to show the effects of the ZnO nano-lubricant in this investigation. In this set-up, the average sliding reciprocating speed was 0.154 to 0.66 m s−1. The stroke length was 71.2 mm. The friction test duration was 20 min and the wear test duration was 300 min to determine the effectiveness of the tribofilm on the frictional surfaces. The normal load was 46-308 N with a contact pressure of 3.73– 24.9 MPa to simulate the boundary lubrication system based on the calculated lambda. The lambda (λ) is the ratio of the lubricant thickness and the root mean square roughness of the ring and liner surfaces [29]. To illustrate the lubrication system, the lambda ratio and oil film thickness were determined using Equations (1) and (2), respectively, as suggested by Hamrock and Dowson [30].
l = hmin srms = hmin∑ Rq = hmin R2a1 + R2a2 √ (1)
hmin R = 3.63 U g E R
( )0.68 (a R)0.49
W E R2
( )−0.073
(1− e−0.68 k) (2)
where hminis the minimum oil film thickness, srms is the root mean square roughness of the liner and ring surfaces, Ra1 is the surface roughness of the liner (0.67 μm) and Ra2 is the surface roughness of the ring (0.58 μm), R is the curvature radius of the ring (∼0.02 m), U is the entraining velocity, W is the contact load, g is the dynamic viscosity of the lubricant at atmospheric pressure (0.086 Pa s), a is the viscosity-pressure coefficient (∼1 × 10−8 m2 N−1) and E is Young’s modulus of the ring (220 GPa). In this study, the calculated lambda ratio (λ) did not exceed 0.9 for all speed and pressure values, which confirms that the contact conditions were within the boundary lubrication regime.
Notably, the friction and wear experiments were reiterated three times for the same testing circumstances to ensure repeatable experimental results, and the average value of these acquired results was taken to minimise the measurement error. The wear rate (mm3 N−1 m−1) of the ring samples was calculated according to the principles of wear rate measurements [31] as follows:
wear rate = V Fn L
(3)
where V is the worn volume in mm3, L is the sliding distance in m and Fn is the normal force in N. The worn volume of the ring was specified via the profiles of the worn scar cross-section using a surface profilometer before and after the wear test. The experimental details of the measurement method were reported by Truhan et al. [32]. According to the principles of wear measurements [31], the wear volume can be calculated by weighing the sample before and after each wear test when the material loss is more than 3 mg.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
The results display the effect of ZnO nano-additives on the kinematic viscosity and the tribological performance of the ring-liner contact compared with the reference oil (10W-40). The worn surface morphologies of the liner and ring specimens of the lubrication with and without ZnO NPs were analysed based on extensive surface scanning. The anti-friction/wear mechanisms are discussed below.
Effect of ZnO NP concentration on the kinematic viscosity and viscosity index
The kinematic viscosity and viscosity index were examined for the reference oil (10W-40) and ZnO
nano-lubricant at two main temperatures, 40°C and 100°C. The kinematic viscosity and viscosity index measurements were conducted in accordance with the GB/T265-1988 and GB/T1995-1998 oil testing standards. Figure 6(a,b) compares the kinematic viscosity and viscosity index for the lubricant samples. When the lubricant oil temperature rises, its viscosity generally declines. Compared with the 10W-40 lube oil, the kinematic viscosity of the nano-lubricant containing various ZnO NP concentrations at 40°C and 100°C decreased dramatically, as shown in Figure 6 (a). This is due to the NPs between the lubricant layers that result in easier relative movement between the lubricant layers, and the NPs can act as a catalyst [11,33]. The reduction mechanism of the viscosity is dependent on the form and surface properties of the NPs, such as the spherical shape and the surface charge that performs the main role in the rheological behaviour (viscosity) of the fluid [34]. Moreover, the viscosity of the engine oil mixed with oleic acid was slightly decreased. The low viscosity reduces the viscous friction of the lubricant and confirms the effective role of the ZnO NPs in reducing frictional losses and enhancing fuel economy. The lower viscosity also results in a lower load-carrying ability. According to Equation (1), the minimum oil film thickness (hmin) decreases with decreasing oil viscosity, which indicates that using a low-viscosity lubricant results in an easier transition from full fluid lubrication to mixed or boundary regimes. This reduction in the viscosity would be a negative outcome for the addition of ZnO NPs. Hence, a suitable recommended viscosity for the engine lubrication is needed to help improve the performance of engines [35]. Figure 6(b) indicates that the viscosity index of the ZnO nano-lubricant increased 9.52–14.28% compared with the engine oil without NPs. The increase in the viscosity index indicates higher lube oil stability with the temperature change, which decreases the shear resistance for the thinning lubricant film.
Effects of the applied load and sliding speed on the friction coefficient
The NP concentration is imperative because they can agglomerate if there is a surplus of NPs in the lube oil, which can increase the friction. To determine the optimum concentration of the ZnO NPs, the coefficient of friction (COF) was measured for various concentrations of ZnO NPs (0.3, 0.6 and 0.8 wt-%). Figure 7 exhibits the average COF for these concentrations under 139 N load and 0.32 m s−1 sliding speed. Although all concentrations of ZnO NPs presented lower COF than the 10W-40, the 0.6 wt-% concentration had the minimum COF of the samples. This occurred because the contact area of the frictional surfaces was saturated by the NPs [29]. Therefore, the concentration of 0.6 wt-% ZnO NPs was applied in the tribological experiments with the following results.
One of the distinguishing features of the piston ring/ cylinder liner contact is that the lubrication mechanism occurs with different types of lubrication regimes (boundary, mixed, hydrodynamic) that happen simultaneously in the reciprocating single stroke (one wear
Figure 6. Effect of ZnO NP concentration on the kinematic viscosity (a) and viscosity index (b).
track). Figure 8 presents a comparison between the COF time history of the ZnO nano-lubricant and engine base oil under a sliding speed of 0.329 m s−1 and 246 N contact load. The friction behaviour revealed that the highest COF was detected at the top and bottom dead centre of the stroke (TDC and BDC). This is due to the low sliding speed, which becomes instantaneously zero at TDC and BDC and limits adequate passage of the lubricant to these positions, resulting in more metal contact between frictional interfaces (boundary lubrication). The lowest COF was in the middle of the stroke due to sufficient lubricant entry (hydrodynamic lubrication) as a result of the highest sliding speed [36]. This behaviour exhibits an interesting aspect of the action of ZnO nanolubricant. In Figure 8, most of the stroke cycles show that the boundary friction at the TDC and BDC positions declined in the case of the ZnO nano-lubricants. This indicated that ZnO nano-lubricant showed greater effectiveness in the boundary lubrication regime. Notably, the average COF over the entire cycle was reduced by 20.51% compared with the engine
oil (Figure 9). The COF was reduced because of the mechanism of the ZnO NPs (converting sliding into rolling friction) and the formation of the lubricating layer on the rubbing surfaces. Hence, this reduction in the COF could reduce frictional power losses in automotive engines.
Figure 9 indicates the influence of a contact load and sliding speed of 46-308 N and 0.154–0.66 m s−1, respectively, on the friction trends for both lubricants (10W-40 and ZnO nano-lubricants). The results show a decline in the COF trend with respect to both the sliding speed and contact load. This might be due to the severity of the contact pressure over the asperities tips with increasing contact load, which led to the fracture and crushing of some of the asperities [8]. The surface roughness of the rubbing surfaces will consequently decline, resulting in the reduction in the boundary COF as it is affected by the variation in surface roughness through the sliding process, as well changes in the surface chemistry. The reduction in the COF with increasing speed was related to the low asperity contact time (metal-to-metal contact) [36]. The real contact area was reduced, causing a decline in the COF with increasing speed. Eventually, the ZnO nano-lubricants revealed a decrease in the COF compared with the reference oil. This is due to the nano-ball bearing effect of the ZnO NPs and the formation of tribofilm (coating layer) on the frictional surfaces.
Effect of the contact load on the specific wear rate
Figure 10 shows the specific wear rate of the ring for ZnO nano-lubricant compared with that of the commercial 10W-40 lubricant considering different loads (from 120 to 280 N), a constant average sliding speed of 0.256 m s−1 and test duration of 300 min after 4.6 km sliding distance. The results showed that the wear rate decreased with increasing normal load. At
high loads, the piston ring wear rate of the ZnO nanolubrication was reduced by 43–88% compared with that of the reference oil. The trend of the wear rate decreased gradually until the load reached 218 N; after that, the wear trend increased until it reached to 1.59E–08 at a load of 280 N due to the damage the ZnO tribofilm on the rubbing surfaces. In addition, the formation of a tribo-layer on the rubbing pairs enhanced the anti-wear properties. The ZnO NPs tribo-layer can carry a portion of the load and separate
the rubbing sliding surfaces to inhibit adhesion (the anti-wear mechanism) [37].

sections.heading: Surface morphology analysis
sections.text:
A case study approach based on EDS, FE-SEM and XPS surfaces analysis was taken to understand the friction and wear reduction mechanisms, including how the solid lubricating film is formed on the frictional surfaces. The morphology of the worn surfaces was examined after 4.6 km sliding distance under a contact load of 308 N, average sliding speed of 0.256 m s−1 and test duration of 300 min. Figure 11(a–f) illustrates the FESEM image, EDS patterns and 3D surface roughness of the ring surface for the ZnO nano-lubricants and 10W-40. The sliding surface of the ring using pure engine oil displayed abrasive wear, wear debris and cracks, as shown in Figure 11(a). The wear debris on the rubbing ring surface confirms the high COF and wear rate results, as presented in Figures 9 and 10. In contrast, the surface lubricated by ZnO nano-lubricants was very smooth without any scratches, which can be attributed to the formation of a smooth tribofilm on the worn ring surface, as shown in Figure
Figure 10. Effect of ZnO nano-lubricants on the ring wear rate under different loads at a 0.256 m s−1 sliding speed.
11(b). The ZnO NP deposition on the sliding surface of the ring was further confirmed by the EDS spectrum analysis with elemental content, as shown in Figure 11 (c,d). As described in Table 2, the tribofilm formed on the worn ring specimen was enriched by the elements of Zn and O and affirmed the existence of ZnO NPs in the composition. Moreover, trace amounts of Ca and S were detected in the case of the nano-lubricants. This implies that the oil additive package was adsorbed by the ZnO NPs on the substrate surface, which confirms the synergistic effects between the ZnO NPs and the oil additive package. In Figure 11(e,f), the 3D surface roughness profile of the ring specimen is presented for the ZnO nano-lubricants and 10W-40.
Table 3 gives the surface parameters of the ring and liner specimens for both the lube oils. The mean surface roughness (Ra) of the piston ring for the ZnO nano-lubricants is 0.36 and 0.44 µm for the surface lubricated by the reference oil; a polished ring worn surface resulted from using the ZnO NPs.
The EDS element mapping and EPMA image shown in Figure 12 exhibit the microstructure and chemical construction of the tribo-boundary film and plastic deformation zone of the ring surface oiled by ZnO nano-lubricants. Based on the EDS mapping characterisation, the tribo-boundary film was composed of C, Ca, Cl. S, P and Zn elements. The EDS mapping also revealed that the elements, i.e. Fe and Si, might come from the underlying substrate metal surface in some regions. This suggested that the worn surface that was not covered completely by the tribofilm and ZnO NPs was more favourable to the nano-ball bearing effect than tribofilm formation. This occurs because the majority of ZnO NPs remain blended with the
engine oil (very low deposition on the worn surface) to produce the mode change of the friction from sliding to rolling friction. This means that the ZnO NPs were more effective in reducing the COF.
Figure 13 compares the microstructure of the EDS line-scanning region of the liner and elemental compositions in the formation of the tribofilm in the case of the ZnO nano-lubricants and the commercial oil (10W-40). Clear signals of P from the oil additive package (ZDDP additive) were observed as well as Si and Fe from the worn liner surface for both the 10W-40 and ZnO nano-lubricants. Notably, the line scans of Cl and Ca in both cases display excessively low signals. This is might be due to sheer background noise. Furthermore, the Fe and Si patterns in the case of the engine oil EDS patterns showed high concentrations on the worn surface of the liner. This means that these elements are the main component of the metal surface and the presence of debris on the worn surface was not observed, as shown in Figure 13. In ZnO nanolubricants, the Fe patterns have a lower intensity in
Figure 12.Microstructure and EDS element maps on the crosssection of the worn piston ring surface using ZnO nanolubricants.
some locations of the worn surfaces but the P pattern displayed higher intensity at the same locations. This means that the P element is the main component contributing to the filling of the pits and grooves, as shown in Figure 13(b). In addition, the Zn signals exhibited very low intensity. This confirms that the ZnO NPs are highly effective in the rolling effect between the rubbing surfaces.
Figure 14 compares the liner morphology for the two lubrication strategies using the EPMA image and 3D surface roughness of the cylinder liner sample. The frictional surface of the liner using engine oil without nano-additives clearly displayed deformation areas and wear debris, as shown in Figure 14(a), due to the disruption of the oil lubricant film in the boundary lubricant regime between the ring and liner. When ZnO NPs was added to the base oil, the debris and
deformation were eliminated and the sliding surface of the liner was comparatively flat and dominated by light abrasive wear, as shown in Figure 14(b). To demonstrate the tribological performance, the 3D surface roughness profile of the liner is presented in Figure 14(c,d). The results show that the mean surface roughness of the cylinder liner was 3.47 ± 0.04 and 3.36 ± 0.05 µm using the commercial lubricant and ZnO NPs, respectively, as indicated in Table 3.
For further elucidation, an XPS experiment was performed to illustrate the chemical structure and valence states of different elements in the tribofilm formed on the worn surfaces during the friction process. Figure 15 displays the XPS surface survey scan spectra of the ring frictional surfaces for both lube oils. The XPS survey scan confirms the existence of Zn originating from the nano-lubricants and C from the oil additive
Figure 13. Elemental distribution on the worn liner surface under lubrication by the reference oil and ZnO nano-lubricant.
package. The survey scan also detected the presence of the Fe 2p signal, which might come from the underlying metal surface at points where it is uncovered in the case of the ring surface lubricated with the standard oil. It is noteworthy that the tribofilm seems free of S 2p and P 2p metals that would be expected to appear as a result of ZDDP decomposition.
Figure 16 shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of the main elements deposited on the worn ring surfaces lubricated by engine oil and ZnO nano-lubricant. Figure 16(a) demonstrates that the O 1s core level spectra of the reference oil showed a broad asymmetric band in the 329–534 eV range and centred at approximately 530 eV that was attributed to the oxidation of the iron (FeO), which occurred during the friction. Moreover, the O 1s signal at 532.38 eV is specific to the SiO2 compound. In Figure 16(b), the core level
spectra of O 1s deconvoluted into three peaks at 530.3 for Zn−O, 531.18 for C=O/C−O and 532.58 eV for C−O−Zn [38]. The Zn 2p spectrum is divided into two peaks at binding energies of 1020.38 and 1043.58 eV attributed to Zn 2p1/2 and 2p3/2, respectively, indicating the formation of Zn2+ ions, which is confirmed in the literature [39,40]. This confirms the effect of the ZnO nano-additive and its contribution to tribofilm formation. The C 1s core level spectra showed peaks at 283.58 and 283.28 eV for the reference oil and nano-lubricants, respectively, which can be attributed to the oxidation of the oil additive package and contaminated carbons on the worn surface. The P 2p core level spectrum showed no contribution to the tribofilm formation, as shown in Figure 16(a,b). Notably, two peaks of Fe 2p at 708.28 and 728.88 eV (corresponding to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively)
Figure 14. EPMA image and 3D surface profile of the worn liner surface. (a) Worn liner surface lubricated by commercial lubricant. (b) Worn liner surface lubricated by ZnO nano-lubricant.
were observed in the case of the reference oil, as shown in Figure 16(a), which means that the worn surface was uncovered by the tribofilm. The higher Zn signal in the case of the nano-lubricants might indicate that the tribofilm provides more uniform coverage of the worn surface, resulting in lower peak intensity of the Fe and Si elements from the underlying metal surface, as illustrated in Figure 16(b).

sections.heading: Concluding remarks
sections.text:
In this study, we investigated the tribological performance of the ring-on-liner assembly lubricated by the ZnO nano-lubricants compared with that of the 10W-40 engine oil. This investigation examined the influence of several parameters such as loads and speeds on the friction and wear. The major conclusions are described below.
(1) The tribological trends of the ring-on-liner contact were improved by 20–23% and 43–88% in terms of friction and wear trends, respectively, compared with the reference oil (10W-40). Moreover, the surface morphologies of the ring and liner revealed that ZnO nano-lubricants produced smoother rubbing surfaces. (2) The kinematic viscosity of ZnO nano-lubricants strongly decreased by 45% due to the presence of ZnO NPs between the lubricant layers leading to an ease of relative movement. The viscosity index
with the ZnO nano-lubricants increased by 12.25% in contrast to the reference oil. (3) The principal reason for the anti-wear is the tribofilm formation mechanism by the ZnO NPs and oil additive package, as exhibited in the microstructure tests via EPMA, EDS and XPS. Notably, the EDS mapping/line-scanning indicated that the ZnO NPs were more favourable for the nano-ball bearing effect between the rubbing surfaces in the contact area due to lower depositions on the sliding pair surfaces. (4) Further investigations should examine the engine tribology, engine fuelling and main engine performance (brake power, torque, frictional power and exhaust emissions) using ZnO-based nanolubrication.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors also wish to thank the editors and reviewers for their precious time and valuable suggestions and comments.

sections.heading: Disclosure statement
sections.text: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors.

sections.heading: Funding
sections.text:
The authors would like to express their deep appreciation to the financial support from the National Natural Science
Foundation of China (NSFC), Project No. 51875423. The authors also acknowledge the continuous support of Hubei Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Automotive Components (Wuhan University of Technology). A. Elagouz gratefully acknowledges the financial support from both the Chinese Scholarship Council (CSC grant number 2016GF124), China and the Minia University, Egypt. Dr. M.K.A. Ali gratefully acknowledges the financial support during the post-doctoral study from Minia University, Egypt.

metadata.abstractText: Automobile engines consume more than 30% of fuel energy as frictional power waste. Therefore, this paper investigated the tribological properties of ZnO nanoparticles (NPs) as a nano-additive to improve the wear and friction trends of the piston ring/cylinder liner interface, especially in boundary lubrication. This improvement occurs due to the formation of a solid tribofilm layer on the sliding surfaces that acts as an indirect coating to help separate and protect the worn pairs. Tribological experiments were carried out under different speeds and loading circumstances using a ring-on-liner reciprocating test bench. The surface morphologies of the tested samples were analysed using EPMA, FE-SEM, a 3D surface profilometer and XPS to illustrate the key mechanisms of the ZnO nano-additives. The tribotest results show that the coefficient of friction and specific wear rate of the ring were reduced by 20–23% and 43–88%, respectively, using the ZnO nano-additives compared with the reference oil. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 2 January 2019 Revised 9 May 2019 Accepted 13 May 2019
